div1.p: Hon. David J Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Subject. The death of Vice C. General Beverly Y. Payne, at North Harvey Ill., U S. A.

Synopsis Mrs Amanda Smith, colored Evangelist 147th St, North Harvey, Ill., U. S. A. under date of Sept. 21, 1900, writes the sister of Vice Consul General, Beverly Y. Payne, of the hopeless and declining condition of her brother, and proposes to forward the remains to Liberia in Nov.
No. 50. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Oct. 26 1900.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have to transmit to you the intelligence, that we are very indefinitely informed here: through the kindess of Mrs. Amanda Smith, the colored Evangelist, 147th Street, North Harvey Ill. under date of Sept. 21, 1899, that General Beverly Y. Payne, of Liberia, United States Vice Consul General of this Consulate General; who sailed from this post for America, March 29, 1900 for treatment, died at the house of our informer Mrs.

Mrs. Amanda Smith, colored Evangelist, 147th Street, North Harvey Ill. at some time near the 21st September 1900. Do we, as well as the surviving relatives here, the kindness, to inquire after, the particulars and if possible, cause his effects &c, which were with him, consisting possibly, only of a travellers outfit, money &c to be forwarded back to Liberia, with whatever information obtainable.

Since we have a Secretary of the Legation, who is by virtue of his office, placed in charge of the Legation, in case of the inability of the Chief of the Mission to perform the duties of the Legation or his absence from the Mission; I hardly see the present necessity for recommending any one for Vice Consul General here; since under

under the new requirement for furnishing bond, in the United States, necessarily intails an annual expense; giving only official title without compensation, which has caused no little annoyance, and has worked very dissatisfactorily to the incumbent; here. However, I await your advice.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith M. R. and C. General.
